You said:
OpenAI Agents SDK
Can you explain this
ChatGPT said:

Great question — and thanks for highlighting the exact phrase.
You selected: “Agents as tools / Handoffs”. Here’s a clear explanation.

What does “Agents as tools / Handoffs” mean?

It means:

One agent can delegate work to another specialized agent, just like calling a tool.

Instead of having one giant agent that does everything, you create multiple focused agents, and they can pass tasks to each other.

Think of it like a team inside your AI system.

Simple real-world analogy (banking-friendly)

Imagine a customer query in a bank:

“I want to increase my credit card limit and also understand the charges”

Instead of one agent handling everything:

  • 🧠 Main Agent (Manager)

    • Understands the user request

    • Decides who should handle what

It hands off tasks to:

  • 💳 Credit Card Policy Agent → understands eligibility rules

  • 📄 Charges Explanation Agent → explains fees clearly

  • 🛡️ Compliance Agent → checks if response is allowed to be given

Each agent is an expert.

That is handoff.

Why call it “Agents as tools”?

Because technically, one agent is treated like a callable tool.

Just like:

  • Tool: get_customer_balance()

  • Agent-tool: call_credit_policy_agent()

So instead of:

“Let me compute this myself…”

The agent does:

“I will call the CreditPolicyAgent and get the answer.”

Very simple technical mental model

text
User → Main Agent
            ↓
    Decides: "This needs specialist"
            ↓
      Calls another Agent
            ↓
      Gets result back
            ↓
      Final answer to user

Why this matters for enterprise (banking use)

This is extremely powerful for:

✅ Separation of responsibility
✅ Governance (each agent has limited scope)
✅ Security (agents don’t see data they shouldn’t)
✅ Auditability (you know which agent decided what)
✅ Scaling teams (different teams own different agents)

Example enterprise architecture:

  • HR Agent (only HR data)

  • Finance Agent (only finance systems)

  • Risk Agent (only risk rules)

  • Orchestrator Agent (coordinates but has no sensitive data)

One-line definition

Agents as tools / handoffs = multi-agent architecture where agents can delegate work to other agents just like calling tools.

  • A visual architecture diagram

  • A Python code example

  • Or a banking POC architecture using this pattern

You said:
OpenAI Agents SDK
Why it's hand off
ChatGPT said:

Great follow-up — the word “handoff” is actually chosen very deliberately.

Why is it called a handoff?

Because conceptually it works like this:

One agent hands over responsibility for a task to another agent.

Not just “asks for help”, but transfers ownership of part of the job.

Simple human analogy

Imagine in a bank branch:

Customer asks you (front desk):

“I want to close my loan early. What are the charges and process?”

You say:

“Let me hand this to the Loan Officer.”

At that moment:

  • You stop working on the details

  • The Loan Officer takes ownership

  • They return with an authoritative answer

That is a handoff.

Not collaboration.
Not parallel brainstorming.
But clear transfer of control for that subtask.

Difference between tool-call and handoff

Tool call:

Agent: "Let me call calculator()"
→ Agent stays fully in control

Handoff:

Agent: "This is not my expertise. Let me transfer this to the Compliance Agent."
→ Another agent temporarily becomes the decision-maker

That’s why the SDK uses the term handoff instead of just “agent calling another agent”.

Why this matters in enterprise systems (like your banking use case)

Because it gives you:

  • Clear accountability
    → “Compliance agent approved this response”

  • Better governance
    → Each agent has strict scope

  • Safer architecture
    → Risk agent never touches PII

  • Easier audits
    → Logs show exact handoff chain

Auditors love this model.

One-line answer

It’s called a handoff because the first agent hands over control and responsibility for a task to another specialized agent, just like humans do in real organizations.

If you want, next I can show you:

  • A visual flow diagram

  • Or a banking-grade architecture using handoffs

  • Or how this compares with Google ADK handoff pattern

Great question — and this is exactly the right thing to ask for enterprise use.

Short answer first:

You do NOT deploy your agent “inside OpenAI”.
You deploy it in your own infrastructure (your cloud, your VPC, your servers).
OpenAI only provides the models + SDK + APIs, not the hosting of your business logic.

Let’s break it down clearly.

Where does the agent actually run?

Your agent is just code (Python / Node / Go) that calls OpenAI APIs.

So you deploy it like any normal backend service.

Typical deployment options:

1. Cloud (most common for enterprise)

  • AWS (Lambda, ECS, EKS, EC2)

  • Azure (App Service, AKS, Functions)

  • GCP (Cloud Run, GKE, Compute Engine)

Example:

You build an agent using Agents SDK → wrap it in FastAPI → deploy on Kubernetes (AKS/EKS)

2. On-premise (banking friendly)

Many banks prefer:

  • Deploy agent service inside internal Kubernetes cluster

  • Calls OpenAI API over secured outbound connection

  • Or via Azure OpenAI private endpoint

Architecture becomes:

java
User UI (internal portal)
        ↓
Your API (on-prem / VPC)
        ↓
Agent service (your code)
        ↓
OpenAI API (model only)

OpenAI never hosts your workflows or business logic.

3. Agent Builder UI (low-code tool)

If you use Agent Builder (visual canvas):

  • The design is hosted in OpenAI platform

  • But real production usage still connects to:

    • Your APIs

    • Your tools

    • Your data sources

Think of it like:

Figma for agents (design)
Your infra for execution

Security controls❌✅

This is why OpenAI says:

“Governance, security, and control remain with you.”

Because deployment is yours.

All OpenAI sees:

Encrypted prompt + tool call context → model response

API Agents | OpenAI
Once I develop the agent using the SDK, how to deploy into chatkit
ChatGPT said:

Great, now we can answer this precisely using the actual page context.

You’re asking:

“Once I develop the agent using the SDK, how do I deploy it into ChatKit?”

Short, honest answer:

You don’t “deploy your SDK agent code into ChatKit”.
ChatKit connects to your agent over an API.

ChatKit is a UI layer, not a runtime for your Python code.

Let’s make it concrete.

Mental model (very important)

LayerWho hosts it
ChatKit (UI)OpenAI (hosted web app)
Your Agent (SDK code)You host this (your laptop, server, cloud)
OpenAI ModelsOpenAI

So the architecture is:

scss
ChatKit (browser UI)
        ↓
Your Agent API (FastAPI / Flask / Express etc.)
        ↓
Your Agents SDK code
        ↓
OpenAI API (models + tools)

ChatKit does not run your Python agent code.
It only calls an HTTP endpoint that you expose.

What you actually need to do

After building your agent using the SDK, you must:

Step 1: Wrap your agent inside an API (example with FastAPI)

Example:

python
from fastapi import FastAPI
from agents import Agent, Runner

app = FastAPI()

agent = Agent(
    name="ResearchAgent",
    instructions="You are a research assistant..."
)

@app.post("/chat")
async def chat(request: dict):
    user_message = request["message"]

    result = await Runner.run(agent, user_message)

    return {"reply": result.final_output}

Run it locally:

bash
uvicorn app:app --port 8000

Now you have:

bash
POST http://localhost:8000/chat

Step 2: Deploy this API somewhere public or reachable

For example:

  • Azure App Service

  • AWS Lambda + API Gateway

  • Cloud Run

  • Kubernetes

  • Internal server (for private use)

You get a URL like:

arduino
https://my-agent.company.com/chat

Step 3: Connect this endpoint to ChatKit

In ChatKit (https://chatkit.studio/), you typically configure:

  • Agent name

  • UI styling

  • And most importantly:

    Backend endpoint URL

So ChatKit becomes:

pgsql
User types message in ChatKit UI
→ ChatKit sends HTTPS request to your endpoint
→ Your agent runs
→ Your API returns response
→ ChatKit displays it

What ChatKit actually gives you

ChatKit handles:

  • Chat UI

  • Conversation display

  • Session handling

  • Styling

  • Login (basic)

  • Embeddable widgets

  • Sharing demos

It does not:

  • Host your Python agent

  • Run your business logic

  • Store your sensitive data

  • Handle enterprise auth

If you want the absolute fastest demo flow

You can do this in under 30–60 minutes:

  1. Write agent in SDK

  2. Wrap with FastAPI

  3. Deploy to:

    • Cloud Run (GCP)

    • Render.com

    • Railway.app

    • Azure App Service

  4. Paste endpoint into ChatKit

  5. You now have a hosted web UI

One-line answer

To deploy an SDK agent into ChatKit, you expose your agent as an HTTP API endpoint, and then configure ChatKit to call that endpoint — ChatKit is just the UI, your agent must run in your infrastructure.

arduino
https://agent.yourcompany.com/chat

❌ You do NOT deploy ChatKit locally

sql

Agent reasoning →
Tool called →
Bad data returned →
Agent used wrong output →
Final response

This is critical for:

  • Regulated environments

  • Incident reviews

  • Model risk management

  • Audit trails

2. Optimization – “How can I make my agent better automatically?”

This is about improving quality and performance over time.

From the page, examples include:

  • Evals (test your agent on many test cases)

  • Prompt optimization (automatically improve prompts)

  • Trace grading (LLM graders scoring runs)

  • Version 2: 81% correct

  • Version 3: 68% correct → regression caught automatically

Without this, you rely on:

“It feels better” (dangerous in enterprise)

With this, you get:

“We improved accuracy from 72% → 81% measured over 500 evals.”

That’s the kind of metric leadership trusts.

3. Orchestration – “How do multiple agents + tools work together reliably?”

This is about managing complex workflows:

  • Multi-agent flows

  • Retry logic

  • Fallback agents

  • Parallel execution

  • Human-in-the-loop steps

  • Conditional branching

  • Long-running tasks

pgsql
User asks about loan closure
↓
Orchestrator agent
↓
Calls Policy Agent
↓
Calls Customer Data Agent
↓
Calls Risk Agent
↓
Combines responses
↓
If confidence low → escalate to human
↓
Return final answer

Orchestration ensures:

  • This flow is reliable

  • Steps happen in correct order

  • Failures are handled

  • Partial success is managed

Without orchestration:

You end up with fragile scripts.

With orchestration:

You get workflow-grade systems.

ChatGPT said:

Great — now we can explain this exactly based on the text on the page you’re viewing, not abstract theory.

The page says:

Trace grading
“Set the pass criteria once and let LLM graders evaluate the last 100—or 1,000—executions of your workflow.”

Let’s unpack that clearly.

What is a “trace” first?

A trace is the full record of one agent run, for example:

  • User input

  • Agent reasoning steps

  • Which tools were called

  • Tool outputs

  • Intermediate decisions

  • Final answer

Think of it like:

A full execution log of your agent for one request.

Example trace:

vbnet
User: "Close my credit card"
Agent: classified intent = card_closure
Agent: calls policy tool
Tool returns policy text
Agent: summarizes process
Final answer returned

That entire flow = one trace.

What does “grading” mean here?

Grading means:

Automatically scoring whether that trace was good or bad.

Instead of humans reviewing thousands of conversations manually, you define criteria like:

  • Was the answer correct?

  • Did it follow policy?

  • Was tone professional?

  • Did it hallucinate?

  • Did it call the right tools?

  • Was sensitive data leaked?

Then an LLM grader evaluates each trace against those criteria.

So Trace Grading =

Automatically reviewing past agent runs (traces) using another LLM acting as a quality evaluator.

Concrete example (banking-style)

Let’s say you run a banking assistant.

You define pass criteria:

  • Must not give financial advice beyond policy

  • Must cite source when explaining fees

  • Must escalate if confidence is low

  • Must not hallucinate charges

You then run trace grading on:

The last 1,000 real customer interactions

You get output like:

  • 91% passed

  • 6% unclear answers

  • 2% policy deviation

  • 1% hallucination detected

Now you have:

  • A measurable quality metric

  • Audit evidence

  • A way to prioritize fixes

Why this is powerful (and new)

Before this, teams had to:

  • Manually read chat logs

  • Sample 20–30 conversations

  • Subjectively judge quality

With trace grading:

  • You can review thousands of runs automatically

  • Continuously monitor production quality

  • Catch regressions quickly

It turns agents from:

“Black box chatbot”
into
“Measurable, auditable system”

Simple one-line definition

Trace grading = automatically scoring past agent executions (traces) using an LLM evaluator against your quality criteria.

Important practical note

This is:

  • A managed capability on OpenAI’s platform tooling

  • Not something you automatically get if you only use SDK + Azure OpenAI

  • But you can build your own version of this (many enterprises do) using:

    • Logged traces

    • A separate “grader agent”

    • Batch evaluation jobs

Great — now we complete the triangle:
Evals vs Trace Grading vs Prompt Optimization

They are three different but connected tools in the Optimize block.

What is Prompt Optimization?

From the page:

“Improve prompts through automatic prompt optimization based on the results of your eval runs.”

Plain meaning:

The system automatically rewrites and tests better versions of your prompt to improve performance — instead of you manually tweaking wording again and again.

Why this exists (real problem)

Normally, teams do this:

“Let me tweak the prompt…”
Test again
“Maybe add more instructions…”
Test again
“Hmm still weak…”
Trial and error for days

Prompt Optimization automates that.

How it works conceptually

You provide:

  • Your current prompt

  • Your eval dataset (test questions + expected behavior)

  • Your success criteria (what “good” means)

The system then:

  1. Generates many alternative prompt variants

  2. Runs Evals on each variant

  3. Measures which performs best

  4. Recommends the improved prompt

So instead of guessing, you get:

“This prompt improves accuracy from 71% → 84% based on evals.”

Simple example

Your original prompt:

“You are a banking assistant. Answer questions politely.”

Eval score: 68%

Prompt optimizer may propose:

“You are a certified banking assistant.
Always follow RBI compliance.
If unsure, say you don’t know.
Provide step-by-step explanations.
Never hallucinate fees or policies.”

New eval score: 82%

You didn’t manually invent that — the system explored variations.

Difference between the three (very clear)

FeatureQuestion it answers
Evals“How good is my agent?”
Trace grading“How good was my agent in real usage?”
Prompt Optimization“How can I automatically improve my prompt?”

Simple analogy (easy to remember)

Think of training for exams:

  • Evals = Mock tests

  • Trace grading = Teacher reviewing your real classwork

  • Prompt Optimization = Personal AI tutor that rewrites your study method to boost your score

Important enterprise reality check

Just like the others:

  • This is a managed feature on OpenAI platform

  • If you use:

    • Agents SDK only

    • Azure OpenAI

    • Your own infra

Then:

You must build your own version of prompt optimization (using eval loops + experimentation pipelines)

Many enterprises do this with:

  • Internal experimentation frameworks

  • A/B testing pipelines

  • MLFlow-style tracking

One-line definition

Prompt Optimization automatically improves your agent’s prompt by testing multiple variants against evals and selecting the best-performing version.

Short, direct answer:
Yes — if you are not using OpenAI’s hosted platform UI, you will need to build your own UI (or dashboards) for Evals and Observability.

Let’s ground this in what your page actually shows.

What the page implies (but doesn’t say explicitly)

On the OpenAI platform (platform.openai.com), features like:

  • Evals

  • Prompt Optimization

  • Trace Grading

  • Observability

come with hosted tooling and dashboards.

But that only applies when you are:

Using the OpenAI SaaS platform experience (Agent Builder, platform UI, etc.)

If instead you are doing:

  • Agents SDK in your own backend

  • Azure OpenAI

  • Your own deployment

  • Your own infra

Then:

OpenAI gives you the capabilities, not the dashboards.

So yes — you own the visualization layer.

Think of it like this analogy

AreaOpenAI Hosted PlatformYour Own Infra (SDK/Azure)
Logs exist✅ Yes✅ Yes (you log them)
Traces exist✅ Yes✅ Yes (you store them)
Evals runner✅ Managed❌ You write the script
Quality scores✅ Shown in UI❌ You compute & show
Dashboards✅ Built-in❌ You build (or use tools)

Same situation as:

  • AWS CloudWatch (managed dashboards)
    vs

  • Your own microservices logging (you must build Grafana dashboards)

The good news (important)

You don’t need to build fancy UIs from scratch.

Most enterprises implement this using existing tools:

For Observability

You can use:

  • Azure Application Insights

  • Azure Monitor

  • ELK (Elastic + Kibana)

  • Datadog

  • Grafana

  • Splunk

You log:

  • Input

  • Output

  • Tool calls

  • Latency

  • Errors

  • Agent decisions

And visualize in dashboards.

For Evals

Typically done as:

  • A Python test runner script

  • Outputs results to:

    • CSV

    • JSON

    • Database

    • Or dashboard tool

Then visualized in:

  • Power BI

  • Grafana

  • Streamlit

  • Simple internal web page

You don’t need a complex UI — even a simple table with scores is powerful in leadership demos.

For Trace Grading

Usually implemented as:

  • Store traces in DB

  • Batch job runs “grader agent”

  • Outputs pass/fail + score

  • Visualized as:

    • % pass

    • % failures

    • Common failure types

Again: can be simple but effective.

What most enterprises actually do

In real banks / enterprises, the stack often looks like:

diff
Agents SDK (your code)
    ↓ logs traces to
Azure App Insights / Datadog / ELK
    ↓
Dashboards built using:
- Azure Monitor Workbooks
- Grafana
- Power BI

Not custom React dashboards from scratch.

The honest answer

OpenAI provides the capability (eval concepts, grading concepts, orchestration ideas).
If you run agents in your own infra (SDK/Azure), you are responsible for logging, storing, and visualizing them.

That’s not a limitation — that’s actually what enterprises prefer, because:

  • They control data

  • They meet compliance

  • They integrate with existing monitoring

✅ Create a file called: app.py

Paste this entire code:

python
import streamlit as st
import json
import uuid
from datetime import datetime

# ----------------------------
# Simple in-memory storage
# ----------------------------
if "traces" not in st.session_state:
    st.session_state.traces = []

# ----------------------------
# Mock Agents
# ----------------------------

def policy_agent(question):
    return "As per bank policy, credit card closure is free if no outstanding dues."

def risk_agent(question):
    return "No risk detected for this request."

def guardrail_check(question):
    if "other customer" in question.lower() or "someone else's" in question.lower():
        return False, "I cannot access or disclose other customers' information."
    return True, None

def orchestrator(user_input):
    trace = {
        "id": str(uuid.uuid4()),
        "time": datetime.now().isoformat(),
        "input": user_input,
        "steps": [],
        "final": ""
    }

    # Guardrail
    allowed, message = guardrail_check(user_input)
    trace["steps"].append({"agent": "Guardrail", "output": str(allowed)})

    if not allowed:
        trace["final"] = message
        st.session_state.traces.append(trace)
        return message

    # Handoff to policy agent
    policy = policy_agent(user_input)
    trace["steps"].append({"agent": "Policy Agent", "output": policy})

    # Handoff to risk agent
    risk = risk_agent(user_input)
    trace["steps"].append({"agent": "Risk Agent", "output": risk})

    final_answer = f"{policy}\n\n{risk}"
    trace["final"] = final_answer

    st.session_state.traces.append(trace)
    return final_answer

# ----------------------------
# Eval + grading
# ----------------------------

EVAL_SET = [
    ("How to close my credit card?", True),
    ("Tell me other customer balance", False),
    ("Is foreclosure charge applicable?", True),
]

def run_evals():
    correct = 0
    for q, expected_safe in EVAL_SET:
        allowed, _ = guardrail_check(q)
        if allowed == expected_safe:
            correct += 1
    return correct, len(EVAL_SET)

def grade_traces():
    results = []
    for t in st.session_state.traces[-10:]:
        passed = "cannot access" not in t["final"].lower()
        results.append(passed)
    return results

# ----------------------------
# UI
# ----------------------------

st.set_page_config(page_title="Banking Agent Platform Demo", layout="wide")
st.title("🏦 Banking Agent Platform Demo")

tabs = st.tabs(["💬 Agent", "🔍 Traces", "📊 Evals", "🧪 Trace Grading"])

# ---- Tab 1: Agent ----
with tabs[0]:
    st.subheader("Chat with Banking Agent")

    user_input = st.text_input("Ask something (try: 'How to close my credit card?')")

    if st.button("Send"):
        response = orchestrator(user_input)
        st.success(response)

# ---- Tab 2: Traces ----
with tabs[1]:
    st.subheader("Observability – Agent Traces")

    for trace in reversed(st.session_state.traces[-5:]):
        with st.expander(f"Trace {trace['id']}"):
            st.write("Input:", trace["input"])
            for step in trace["steps"]:
                st.write(f"➡️ {step['agent']}: {step['output']}")
            st.write("Final:", trace["final"])

# ---- Tab 3: Evals ----
with tabs[2]:
    st.subheader("Agent Evals")

    if st.button("Run Evals"):
        score, total = run_evals()
        st.metric("Accuracy", f"{score}/{total}")
        st.progress(score / total)

# ---- Tab 4: Trace grading ----
with tabs[3]:
    st.subheader("Trace Grading (last 10 traces)")

    if st.button("Grade Traces"):
        grades = grade_traces()
        passed = sum(grades)
        total = len(grades)
        st.metric("Pass Rate", f"{passed}/{total}")
        st.write("Per-trace results:", grades)

2. Create file: banking_agent_demo.py

This is a single-file full working demo using the real SDK.

python
import streamlit as st
from agents import Agent, Runner, function_tool
import uuid
from datetime import datetime

# -----------------------
# Storage for observability
# -----------------------
if "traces" not in st.session_state:
    st.session_state.traces = []

# -----------------------
# Tools (real tools exposed to agent)
# -----------------------

@function_tool
def policy_lookup(topic: str) -> str:
    """Lookup banking policy based on topic"""
    if "credit card" in topic.lower():
        return "Credit card closure is free if no outstanding dues exist."
    if "foreclosure" in topic.lower():
        return "Personal loan foreclosure has 2% penalty after 12 months."
    return "No policy found."

@function_tool
def risk_check(user_request: str) -> str:
    """Run basic risk assessment"""
    if "fraud" in user_request.lower():
        return "Potential risk detected. Escalation recommended."
    return "No risk detected."

# -----------------------
# Guardrail logic
# -----------------------

def guardrail(input_text):
    blocked = ["other customer", "someone else's balance", "steal", "hack"]
    for b in blocked:
        if b in input_text.lower():
            return False, "Request violates banking data privacy policy."
    return True, None

# -----------------------
# Agents
# -----------------------

policy_agent = Agent(
    name="PolicyAgent",
    instructions="You are a banking policy expert. Use policy_lookup tool when needed.",
    tools=[policy_lookup],
)

risk_agent = Agent(
    name="RiskAgent",
    instructions="You are a banking risk analyst. Use risk_check tool to assess risk.",
    tools=[risk_check],
)

orchestrator = Agent(
    name="OrchestratorAgent",
    instructions="""
You are the main banking assistant.
You may handoff to PolicyAgent for policy questions.
You may handoff to RiskAgent for risk validation.
Always provide clear and professional answers.
""",
    handoffs=[policy_agent, risk_agent],
)

# -----------------------
# Run agent + capture trace
# -----------------------

def run_agent(user_input):
    trace = {
        "id": str(uuid.uuid4()),
        "time": datetime.now().isoformat(),
        "input": user_input,
        "events": [],
        "final": ""
    }

    # Guardrail
    allowed, msg = guardrail(user_input)
    trace["events"].append({"stage": "guardrail", "result": allowed})

    if not allowed:
        trace["final"] = msg
        st.session_state.traces.append(trace)
        return msg

    # Run agent
    result = Runner.run_sync(orchestrator, user_input)

    trace["final"] = result.final_output
    trace["events"].append({"stage": "agent_output", "output": result.final_output})

    st.session_state.traces.append(trace)
    return result.final_output

# -----------------------
# Evals
# -----------------------

EVAL_SET = [
    ("How do I close my credit card?", True),
    ("Tell me other customer's balance", False),
    ("Is foreclosure charge applicable?", True),
]

def run_evals():
    correct = 0
    for q, expected_allowed in EVAL_SET:
        allowed, _ = guardrail(q)
        if allowed == expected_allowed:
            correct += 1
    return correct, len(EVAL_SET)

# -----------------------
# Trace grading
# -----------------------

def grade_traces():
    results = []
    for t in st.session_state.traces[-10:]:
        good = "violates" not in t["final"].lower()
        results.append(good)
    return results

# -----------------------
# Streamlit UI
# -----------------------

st.set_page_config(page_title="🏦 Banking Agent (Real OpenAI SDK)", layout="wide")
st.title("🏦 Banking Agent Demo (Real OpenAI Agents SDK)")

tabs = st.tabs(["💬 Agent", "🔍 Traces", "📊 Evals", "🧪 Trace Grading"])

# ---- Agent tab ----
with tabs[0]:
    st.subheader("Chat with Banking Agent")
    user_input = st.text_input("Ask something", placeholder="Try: How do I close my credit card?")

    if st.button("Send"):
        if user_input:
            response = run_agent(user_input)
            st.success(response)

# ---- Traces ----
with tabs[1]:
    st.subheader("Observability – Agent Traces")
    for trace in reversed(st.session_state.traces[-5:]):
        with st.expander(f"Trace {trace['id']}"):
            st.write("Input:", trace["input"])
            st.write("Events:", trace["events"])
            st.write("Final:", trace["final"])

# ---- Evals ----
with tabs[2]:
    st.subheader("Agent Evals")
    if st.button("Run evals"):
        score, total = run_evals()
        st.metric("Eval Accuracy", f"{score}/{total}")
        st.progress(score / total)

# ---- Trace grading ----
with tabs[3]:
    st.subheader("Trace grading (last 10 traces)")
    if st.button("Grade traces"):
        grades = grade_traces()
        passed = sum(grades)
        st.metric("Pass rate", f"{passed}/{len(grades)}")
        st.write(grades)

how to stop stramlit
ChatGPT said:

To stop a running Streamlit app, do this:

✅ If you started it from Terminal / Command Prompt

You likely ran:

bash
streamlit run banking_agent_demo.py

In that same terminal window:

➡️ Press Ctrl + C

That will immediately stop the Streamlit server.

If Ctrl + C doesn’t work (rare cases)

You can manually kill the process.

On Mac / Linux:

bash

Here’s the quick checklist to make sure it works correctly.

Create a file named .env in the same folder as your Python script:

ini
OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

No quotes needed.

✅ Your Python code must load it

Since you’re using .env, you need this in your code:

python
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import os

load_dotenv()

api_key = os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY")

If you're using openai-agents, you don’t even need to pass the key explicitly — the SDK automatically reads OPENAI_API_KEY from environment variables.

✅ Make sure you installed python-dotenv

bash
pip install python-dotenv

ProblemFix

Spaces around =Use OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-...
.env in different folderPut it in same folder as your script
Forgot load_dotenv()Add it at top of code

Below is a single-file, production-style demo that uses:

  • ✅ Real Agent, Runner, handoffs

  • ✅ Trace grading

You can copy-paste this and run it.

1. Install dependencies

bash
pip install streamlit openai-agents python-dotenv

Your .env file:

ini
OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

2. Create file: banking_agent_app.py

Paste everything below into the file.

python
import streamlit as st
from agents import Agent, Runner, function_tool
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import uuid
from datetime import datetime

# Load .env
load_dotenv()

# ------------------------
# Session storage
# ------------------------
if "traces" not in st.session_state:
    st.session_state.traces = []

# ------------------------
# Tools
# ------------------------

@function_tool
def policy_lookup(query: str) -> str:
    """Lookup banking policies"""
    q = query.lower()
    if "credit card" in q:
        return "Credit card closure is free if there are no outstanding dues."
    if "foreclosure" in q:
        return "Personal loan foreclosure attracts a 2% penalty after 12 EMIs."
    if "home loan" in q:
        return "Home loan foreclosure has no penalty for floating rate loans."
    return "No policy found for this query."

@function_tool
def risk_check(text: str) -> str:
    """Simple risk check"""
    if "fraud" in text.lower():
        return "High risk detected. Recommend escalation to human agent."
    return "No significant risk detected."

# ------------------------
# Guardrails
# ------------------------

def guardrail_check(user_input: str):
    blocked_phrases = [
        "other customer",
        "someone else's",
        "hack",
        "steal",
        "bypass",
        "account number"
    ]
    for phrase in blocked_phrases:
        if phrase in user_input.lower():
            return False, "❌ This request violates banking data privacy policy."
    return True, None

# ------------------------
# Agents
# ------------------------

policy_agent = Agent(
    name="PolicyAgent",
    instructions="""
You are a banking policy expert.
Always use the policy_lookup tool when policy information is required.
Give short, professional answers.
""",
    tools=[policy_lookup],
)

risk_agent = Agent(
    name="RiskAgent",
    instructions="""
You are a banking risk analyst.
Always run risk_check before approving sensitive actions.
""",
    tools=[risk_check],
)

orchestrator_agent = Agent(
    name="OrchestratorAgent",
    instructions="""
You are the main banking assistant.
Decide whether to hand off to PolicyAgent or RiskAgent.
Always provide final answer professionally.
""",
    handoffs=[policy_agent, risk_agent],
)

# ------------------------
# Run agent + collect trace
# ------------------------

def run_agent(user_input: str):
    trace = {
        "id": str(uuid.uuid4()),
        "time": datetime.now().isoformat(),
        "input": user_input,
        "events": [],
        "final": ""
    }

    # Guardrail
    allowed, msg = guardrail_check(user_input)
    trace["events"].append({"stage": "guardrail", "allowed": allowed})

    if not allowed:
        trace["final"] = msg
        st.session_state.traces.append(trace)
        return msg

    # Run real agent
    result = Runner.run_sync(orchestrator_agent, user_input)

    trace["events"].append({"stage": "agent_run"})
    trace["final"] = result.final_output

    st.session_state.traces.append(trace)
    return result.final_output

# ------------------------
# Evals
# ------------------------

EVAL_SET = [
    ("How do I close my credit card?", True),
    ("Tell me other customer's balance", False),
    ("Is foreclosure charge applicable?", True),
    ("Can you hack an account?", False),
]

def run_evals():
    correct = 0
    for question, expected_allowed in EVAL_SET:
        allowed, _ = guardrail_check(question)
        if allowed == expected_allowed:
            correct += 1
    return correct, len(EVAL_SET)

# ------------------------
# Trace grading
# ------------------------

def grade_traces():
    results = []
    for t in st.session_state.traces[-10:]:
        good = "violates" not in t["final"].lower()
        results.append(good)
    return results

# ------------------------
# Streamlit UI
# ------------------------

st.set_page_config(page_title="🏦 Banking Agent Demo", layout="wide")
st.title("🏦 Banking Agent Platform Demo (Real OpenAI Agents SDK)")

tabs = st.tabs(["💬 Agent", "🔍 Observability", "📊 Evals", "🧪 Trace Grading"])

# --- Agent ---
with tabs[0]:
    st.subheader("Chat with Banking Agent")
    user_input = st.text_input("Ask something", placeholder="Try: How do I close my credit card?")
    if st.button("Send"):
        if user_input:
            response = run_agent(user_input)
            st.success(response)

# --- Observability ---
with tabs[1]:
    st.subheader("Agent Traces")
    for trace in reversed(st.session_state.traces[-5:]):
        with st.expander(f"Trace {trace['id']}"):
            st.write("Time:", trace["time"])
            st.write("Input:", trace["input"])
            st.write("Events:", trace["events"])
            st.write("Final:", trace["final"])

# --- Evals ---
with tabs[2]:
    st.subheader("Eval Dashboard")
    if st.button("Run Evals"):
        score, total = run_evals()
        st.metric("Accuracy", f"{score}/{total}")
        st.progress(score / total)

# --- Trace grading ---
with tabs[3]:
    st.subheader("Trace Grading")
    if st.button("Grade Recent Traces"):
        grades = grade_traces()
        passed = sum(grades)
        st.metric("Pass Rate", f"{passed}/{len(grades)}")
        st.write(grades)

3. Run it

bash
streamlit run banking_agent_app.py

You’re right to challenge my earlier statement. The page clearly shows that ChatKit is not only a SaaS UI — it also supports self-hosted / advanced integration.

Let’s go through this carefully, grounded in the page you shared, and clarify the real picture.

First: What the ChatKit page actually says (important)

The docs explicitly say:

There are two ways to implement ChatKit:

  1. Recommended integration – Embed ChatKit in your frontend, let OpenAI host and scale the backend (Agent Builder workflows)

  2. Advanced integration – Run ChatKit on your own infrastructure. Use the ChatKit SDK and connect to any agentic backend.

So the truth is:

✅ ChatKit can be used as a framework
✅ You can self-host with the Python SDK
✅ You can connect it to your own backend agents
❌ You are not forced to use OpenAI-hosted Agent Builder

This is more powerful than what most people assume.

Let’s decode ChatKit properly

ChatKit is actually three things:

1. A UI framework (frontend widgets)

  • React components: @openai/chatkit-react

  • JS SDK: chatkit-js

  • Embeddable script:

    html
    <script src="https://cdn.platform.openai.com/deployments/chatkit/chatkit.js"></script>

  • Provides:

    • Chat UI

    • Message bubbles

    • Typing indicators

    • File uploads

    • Tool invocation visualization

    • Chain-of-thought visualizations

    • Widgets

    • Themes

👉 This part is like a ready-made ChatGPT UI kit.

2. A backend helper SDK (Python SDK)

The docs link to:

  • https://github.com/openai/chatkit-python

This SDK helps you:

  • Manage sessions

  • Handle auth tokens

  • Store chat history

  • Connect UI ↔ your agent backend

  • Enforce access control

This means:

You can run everything inside your infra
and ChatKit becomes just a framework + protocol

3. Two architectural modes

Mode A: OpenAI-hosted backend (easy SaaS mode)

Flow:

markdown
Your UI
 → ChatKit widget
   → OpenAI backend
     → Agent Builder workflow

You:

  • Design agent in Agent Builder

  • Use ChatKit to embed UI

  • OpenAI hosts agent execution

This is the "SaaS" style.

Mode B: Self-hosted (enterprise mode)

This is what the docs call Advanced integration:

Flow:

java
Your UI (ChatKit React / JS)
 → Your backend (FastAPI using chatkit-python SDK)
   → Your own agent backend (Agents SDK / LangGraph / ADK / etc.)
     → OpenAI models (or Azure OpenAI)

Here:

  • You host backend

  • You control data

  • You control auth

  • You control logs

  • You control compliance

  • You can even use Azure OpenAI instead of OpenAI

👉 In this mode, ChatKit is effectively a UI framework + session protocol, not a SaaS product.

What that means for your earlier concern

Earlier you asked:

“We should use only our UI, ChatKit is SaaS, right?”

Updated accurate answer:

ChatKit can be used either as SaaS or as a self-hosted UI framework.
If you use Advanced Integration, you can fully run it inside your infrastructure.

So for enterprise:

  • You can use ChatKit

  • You can host backend yourself

  • You can keep data inside your network

  • You can plug it into your own Agents SDK backend

This is a very different story than “just SaaS”.

What OpenAI is really offering with ChatKit (strategically)

They are offering:

A standardized, production-grade chat UX framework for agents

Instead of every enterprise building:

  • Chat UI

  • Streaming UI

  • Tool visualizations

  • Session handling

  • Attachments

  • Widgets

  • Message rendering

You get it out-of-the-box.

Think of it like:

  • Material UI for agents

  • Or Bootstrap for chat agents

  • Or Teams UI SDK for bots

When ChatKit makes sense for you

ChatKit is a good choice if:

  • You want fast, polished UI

  • You don’t want to build React chat from scratch

  • You want widgets, file uploads, visualization

  • You are okay using their SDK patterns

  • You want to connect to your own backend

ChatKit may not be ideal if:

  • Your org mandates strict internal UI framework

  • You need total UI control (pixel-perfect)

  • Your frontend team already has strong design systems

  • You want zero vendor UI dependency

Step 1: Install dependencies

pip install fastapi uvicorn python-dotenv openai-agents chatkit-python

Your .env:

ini
OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-xxxx

Step 2: Backend (FastAPI + Agents SDK + ChatKit)

Create a file: server.py

This backend does 3 things:

  1. Creates ChatKit sessions

  2. Accepts messages from ChatKit

  3. Runs your real Banking Agent

python
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from fastapi import FastAPI, Body
from agents import Agent, Runner, function_tool
from chatkit import ChatKitServer
from pydantic import BaseModel

load_dotenv()

app = FastAPI()

# -----------------------------
# ChatKit server helper
# -----------------------------
chatkit = ChatKitServer(api_key=os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"])

# -----------------------------
# Tools
# -----------------------------
@function_tool
def policy_lookup(query: str) -> str:
    if "credit card" in query.lower():
        return "Credit card closure is free if no outstanding dues exist."
    if "foreclosure" in query.lower():
        return "Personal loan foreclosure carries 2% penalty after 12 EMIs."
    return "No matching policy found."

@function_tool
def risk_check(text: str) -> str:
    if "fraud" in text.lower():
        return "⚠️ High risk. Escalation recommended."
    return "No risk detected."

# -----------------------------
# Agents
# -----------------------------
policy_agent = Agent(
    name="PolicyAgent",
    instructions="You are a banking policy expert. Use policy_lookup.",
    tools=[policy_lookup],
)

risk_agent = Agent(
    name="RiskAgent",
    instructions="You are a banking risk expert. Use risk_check.",
    tools=[risk_check],
)

orchestrator = Agent(
    name="BankingAssistant",
    instructions="""
You are a professional banking assistant.
You may handoff to PolicyAgent or RiskAgent.
Always provide safe, compliant answers.
""",
    handoffs=[policy_agent, risk_agent],
)

# -----------------------------
# Guardrails
# -----------------------------
def guardrail(user_text: str):
    banned = ["other customer", "hack", "steal", "bypass"]
    for b in banned:
        if b in user_text.lower():
            return False, "❌ This violates data privacy policy."
    return True, None

# -----------------------------
# ChatKit session endpoint
# -----------------------------
@app.post("/chatkit/session")
def create_session():
    session = chatkit.create_session()
    return {"client_secret": session.client_secret}

# -----------------------------
# ChatKit message endpoint
# -----------------------------
class ChatRequest(BaseModel):
    message: str

@app.post("/chat")
def chat(req: ChatRequest):
    allowed, msg = guardrail(req.message)
    if not allowed:
        return {"reply": msg}

    result = Runner.run_sync(orchestrator, req.message)
    return {"reply": result.final_output}

Run backend:

bash
uvicorn server:app --reload

Now your backend runs at:

arduino
http://localhost:8000

Step 3: Frontend (ChatKit UI)

You have two easy options:

Option A (Fastest): Use ChatKit Widget (no React build)

Create a simple file: index.html

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <script src="https://cdn.platform.openai.com/deployments/chatkit/chatkit.js"></script>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div id="chat" style="height:600px;width:400px;"></div>

    <script>
      const chat = document.getElementById("chat");

      chatkit.mount(chat, {
        api: {
          async getClientSecret() {
            const res = await fetch("http://localhost:8000/chatkit/session", {
              method: "POST"
            });
            const data = await res.json();
            return data.client_secret;
          },
        },
        backend: {
          async sendMessage(message) {
            const res = await fetch("http://localhost:8000/chat", {
              method: "POST",
              headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
              body: JSON.stringify({ message })
            });
            const data = await res.json();
            return data.reply;
          }
        }
      });
    </script>
  </body>
</html>

Open this file in browser.

You now have:

  • A real ChatKit UI

  • Talking to your backend

  • Which calls your real Banking Agent

  • With real multi-agent orchestration

Use:

  • React

  • @openai/chatkit-react

  • Corporate design system

  • Auth, RBAC, etc.

4. backend/agent.py

(Real Agents SDK + tools + guardrails + multi-agent)

python
from agents import Agent, Runner, function_tool
from storage import add_trace
import uuid
from datetime import datetime

# -------------------
# Tools
# -------------------

@function_tool
def policy_lookup(query: str) -> str:
    q = query.lower()
    if "credit card" in q:
        return "Credit card closure is free if no outstanding dues exist."
    if "foreclosure" in q:
        return "Personal loan foreclosure attracts 2% penalty after 12 EMIs."
    if "home loan" in q:
        return "Home loan foreclosure has no penalty on floating rate."
    return "No policy found."

@function_tool
def risk_check(text: str) -> str:
    if "fraud" in text.lower():
        return "⚠️ Risk detected. Escalation recommended."
    return "No risk detected."

# -------------------
# Agents
# -------------------

policy_agent = Agent(
    name="PolicyAgent",
    instructions="You are a banking policy expert. Use policy_lookup.",
    tools=[policy_lookup],
)

risk_agent = Agent(
    name="RiskAgent",
    instructions="You are a banking risk expert. Use risk_check.",
    tools=[risk_check],
)

orchestrator = Agent(
    name="BankingAssistant",
    instructions="""
You are a professional banking assistant.
Delegate policy queries to PolicyAgent.
Delegate risk-related queries to RiskAgent.
Always be safe and compliant.
""",
    handoffs=[policy_agent, risk_agent],
)

# -------------------
# Guardrail
# -------------------

def guardrail(text: str):
    banned = ["other customer", "hack", "steal", "bypass"]
    for b in banned:
        if b in text.lower():
            return False, "❌ This violates banking privacy policy."
    return True, None

# -------------------
# Run agent
# -------------------

def run_agent(user_input: str):
    trace = {
        "id": str(uuid.uuid4()),
        "time": datetime.now().isoformat(),
        "input": user_input,
        "steps": [],
        "final": None,
    }

    allowed, msg = guardrail(user_input)
    trace["steps"].append({"guardrail": allowed})

    if not allowed:
        trace["final"] = msg
        add_trace(trace)
        return msg

    result = Runner.run_sync(orchestrator, user_input)

    trace["steps"].append({"agent": "orchestrator"})
    trace["final"] = result.final_output

    add_trace(trace)
    return result.final_output

5. backend/evals.py

(Evals + trace grading)

python
from agent import guardrail
from storage import get_traces

EVAL_SET = [
    ("How do I close my credit card?", True),
    ("Tell me other customer's balance", False),
    ("Is foreclosure charge applicable?", True),
    ("Can you hack account?", False),
]

def run_evals():
    correct = 0
    for q, expected in EVAL_SET:
        allowed, _ = guardrail(q)
        if allowed == expected:
            correct += 1
    return correct, len(EVAL_SET)

def grade_traces():
    traces = get_traces()
    graded = []
    for t in traces:
        passed = "violates" not in t["final"].lower()
        graded.append({"id": t["id"], "pass": passed})
    return graded

6. backend/main.py

(FastAPI API + admin endpoints)

python
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel
from agent import run_agent
from storage import get_traces
from evals import run_evals, grade_traces

app = FastAPI()

class ChatRequest(BaseModel):
    message: str

@app.post("/chat")
def chat(req: ChatRequest):
    reply = run_agent(req.message)
    return {"reply": reply}

@app.get("/admin/traces")
def traces():
    return get_traces()

@app.get("/admin/evals")
def evals():
    score, total = run_evals()
    return {"score": score, "total": total}

@app.get("/admin/grading")
def grading():
    return grade_traces()

Run backend:

bash
uvicorn backend.main:app --reload

API runs at:

arduino
http://localhost:8000

7. frontend/index.html

(ChatKit-like professional UI, self-hosted style)

This is a polished chat UI (not Streamlit) that talks to your backend.

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>Banking AI Assistant</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: Arial; background:#f6f8fa; }
    #chat { max-width: 700px; margin: 50px auto; background: white; padding: 20px; border-radius: 12px; }
    .msg { margin: 10px 0; }
    .user { font-weight: bold; }
    .bot { color: #0066cc; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <div id="chat">
    <h2>🏦 Banking AI Assistant</h2>
    <div id="messages"></div>
    <input id="input" placeholder="Ask something..." style="width:80%" />
    <button onclick="send()">Send</button>
    <hr>
    <a href="http://localhost:8000/admin/traces" target="_blank">View Traces</a> |
    <a href="http://localhost:8000/admin/evals" target="_blank">Run Evals</a> |
    <a href="http://localhost:8000/admin/grading" target="_blank">Trace Grading</a>
  </div>

<script>
async function send() {
  const input = document.getElementById("input");
  const text = input.value;
  if (!text) return;

  add("You", text, "user");
  input.value = "";

  const res = await fetch("http://localhost:8000/chat", {
    method: "POST",
    headers: {"Content-Type":"application/json"},
    body: JSON.stringify({message: text})
  });

  const data = await res.json();
  add("Agent", data.reply, "bot");
}

function add(sender, text, cls) {
  const div = document.createElement("div");
  div.className = "msg " + cls;
  div.innerHTML = `<span class="${cls}">${sender}:</span> ${text}`;
  document.getElementById("messages").appendChild(div);
}
</script>
</body>
</html>

frontend/index.html

You previously created:

css

│

And in backend/main.py you have:

This will fail because agent.py is inside the backend folder, not in the root.

Change imports inside backend/main.py from:

python

to:

python

to:

Inside the backend/ folder, create a file:

bash
backend/__init__.py

It can be empty. This tells Python:

"backend is a package"

Without this, imports can break.

From the project root (not inside backend):

✅ This is important.
Do not run uvicorn from inside backend/.

You said:
ChatKit | OpenAI API
this is not working http://localhost:8000/frontend/index.html
ChatGPT said:

Got it — that URL fails because FastAPI is not serving your frontend/ folder by default.
Right now, http://localhost:8000 only serves API routes like /chat, /admin/traces, etc.

So when you try:

bash
http://localhost:8000/frontend/index.html

FastAPI simply has no route configured to serve that file.

Let’s fix it properly.

✅ Correct fix: Tell FastAPI to serve your frontend folder

Open this file:

bash
backend/main.py

Add these imports at the top:

python
from fastapi.staticfiles import StaticFiles
from fastapi.responses import FileResponse
import os

Then add this code after app = FastAPI():

python
# Serve frontend folder
frontend_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "..", "frontend")

app.mount("/frontend", StaticFiles(directory=frontend_path), name="frontend")

@app.get("/")
def serve_index():
    return FileResponse(os.path.join(frontend_path, "index.html"))

✅ Now your URLs will work

Restart uvicorn:

bash
uvicorn backend.main:app --reload

Now open in browser:

👉 Main UI (chat app):

arduino
http://localhost:8000/

👉 Direct access to file:

bash
http://localhost:8000/frontend/index.html

Both will work.

Why it was failing before

FastAPI by default:

  • Serves only API routes you define (/chat, /admin/...)

  • Does NOT serve files from disk unless you explicitly mount them

So without StaticFiles, the frontend was invisible to the server.

3️⃣ backend/agent.py

python
from agents import Agent, Runner, function_tool
from backend.storage import add_trace
import uuid
from datetime import datetime

# -------------------
# Tools
# -------------------

@function_tool
def policy_lookup(query: str) -> str:
    q = query.lower()
    if "credit card" in q:
        return "Credit card closure is free if no outstanding dues exist."
    if "foreclosure" in q:
        return "Personal loan foreclosure attracts 2% penalty after 12 EMIs."
    if "home loan" in q:
        return "Home loan foreclosure has no penalty on floating rate loans."
    return "No policy found."

@function_tool
def risk_check(text: str) -> str:
    if "fraud" in text.lower():
        return "⚠️ Risk detected. Escalation recommended."
    return "No risk detected."

# -------------------
# Agents
# -------------------

policy_agent = Agent(
    name="PolicyAgent",
    instructions="You are a banking policy expert. Use policy_lookup tool.",
    tools=[policy_lookup],
)

risk_agent = Agent(
    name="RiskAgent",
    instructions="You are a banking risk expert. Use risk_check tool.",
    tools=[risk_check],
)

orchestrator = Agent(
    name="BankingAssistant",
    instructions="""
You are a professional banking assistant.
Delegate policy queries to PolicyAgent.
Delegate risk queries to RiskAgent.
Always be safe and compliant.
""",
    handoffs=[policy_agent, risk_agent],
)

# -------------------
# Guardrail
# -------------------

def guardrail(text: str):
    banned = ["other customer", "hack", "steal", "bypass"]
    for b in banned:
        if b in text.lower():
            return False, "❌ This violates banking data privacy policy."
    return True, None

# -------------------
# Run agent
# -------------------

def run_agent(user_input: str):
    trace = {
        "id": str(uuid.uuid4()),
        "time": datetime.now().isoformat(),
        "input": user_input,
        "steps": [],
        "final": None,
    }

    allowed, msg = guardrail(user_input)
    trace["steps"].append({"guardrail": allowed})

    if not allowed:
        trace["final"] = msg
        add_trace(trace)
        return msg

    result = Runner.run_sync(orchestrator, user_input)

    trace["steps"].append({"agent": "orchestrator"})
    trace["final"] = result.final_output

    add_trace(trace)
    return result.final_output

4️⃣ backend/evals.py

python
from backend.agent import guardrail
from backend.storage import get_traces

EVAL_SET = [
    ("How do I close my credit card?", True),
    ("Tell me other customer's balance", False),
    ("Is foreclosure charge applicable?", True),
    ("Can you hack an account?", False),
]

def run_evals():
    correct = 0
    for q, expected in EVAL_SET:
        allowed, _ = guardrail(q)
        if allowed == expected:
            correct += 1
    return correct, len(EVAL_SET)

def grade_traces():
    traces = get_traces()
    graded = []
    for t in traces:
        passed = "violates" not in t["final"].lower()
        graded.append({"id": t["id"], "pass": passed})
    return graded

5️⃣ backend/main.py

✅ This now serves the frontend correctly

python
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel
from backend.agent import run_agent
from backend.storage import get_traces
from backend.evals import run_evals, grade_traces

from fastapi.staticfiles import StaticFiles
from fastapi.responses import FileResponse
import os

app = FastAPI()

# ---------------------------
# Serve frontend
# ---------------------------
frontend_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "..", "frontend")

app.mount("/frontend", StaticFiles(directory=frontend_path), name="frontend")

@app.get("/")
def serve_ui():
    return FileResponse(os.path.join(frontend_path, "index.html"))

# ---------------------------
# API endpoints
# ---------------------------

class ChatRequest(BaseModel):
    message: str

@app.post("/chat")
def chat(req: ChatRequest):
    reply = run_agent(req.message)
    return {"reply": reply}

@app.get("/admin/traces")
def traces():
    return get_traces()

@app.get("/admin/evals")
def evals():
    score, total = run_evals()
    return {"score": score, "total": total}

@app.get("/admin/grading")
def grading():
    return grade_traces()

async function send() {

}

const chat = document.getElementById("chat");

function addMessage(text, cls="bot") {
  const div = document.createElement("div");
  div.className = "msg " + cls;
  div.innerText = text;
  chat.appendChild(div);
  chat.scrollTop = chat.scrollHeight;
  return div;
}

function addSystem(text) {
  const div = document.createElement("div");
  div.className = "msg system";
  div.innerText = text;
  chat.appendChild(div);
  chat.scrollTop = chat.scrollHeight;
}

function addWidget() {
  const div = document.createElement("div");

      </div>
    </div>`;
  chat.appendChild(div);
}

async function send() {
  const input = document.getElementById("input");
  const text = input.value.trim();
  if (!text) return;

  addMessage(text, "user");
  input.value = "";

  addSystem("Agent is reasoning...");
  const typing = addMessage("...", "bot");

  const res = await fetch("/chat", {
    method: "POST",
    headers: {"Content-Type":"application/json"},
    body: JSON.stringify({message: text})
  });

  const data = await res.json();

  // Fake streaming effect
  typing.innerText = "";
  for (let ch of data.reply) {
    typing.innerText += ch;
    await new Promise(r => setTimeout(r, 10));
  }

  // Demo widget if loan related
  if (text.toLowerCase().includes("loan")) {
    addWidget();
  }
}
</script>
</body>
</html>

✅ Architecture (real ChatKit flow)

pgsql
Browser (ChatKit UI from CDN)
   ↓
ChatKit JS → calls your backend: /chatkit/session
   ↓
Your FastAPI issues client_secret
   ↓
ChatKit connects session
   ↓
ChatKit sends messages → your /chat endpoint
   ↓
Your Agents SDK runs
   ↓
Response comes back to ChatKit UI

This matches the official docs.

1. Update backend: backend/main.py

Add a ChatKit session endpoint.

Replace your backend/main.py with this version:

python
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel
from backend.agent import run_agent
from backend.storage import get_traces
from backend.evals import run_evals, grade_traces

from fastapi.staticfiles import StaticFiles
from fastapi.responses import FileResponse
import os

# NEW
from openai import OpenAI
import uuid

client = OpenAI()

app = FastAPI()

# ---------------------------
# Serve frontend
# ---------------------------
frontend_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "..", "frontend")
app.mount("/frontend", StaticFiles(directory=frontend_path), name="frontend")

@app.get("/")
def serve_ui():
    return FileResponse(os.path.join(frontend_path, "index.html"))

# ---------------------------
# ChatKit session endpoint (REAL)
# ---------------------------
@app.post("/chatkit/session")
def create_chatkit_session():
    session = client.chatkit.sessions.create(
        user=str(uuid.uuid4())
    )
    return {"client_secret": session.client_secret}

# ---------------------------
# Chat endpoint (used by ChatKit backend adapter)
# ---------------------------
class ChatRequest(BaseModel):
    message: str

@app.post("/chat")
def chat(req: ChatRequest):
    reply = run_agent(req.message)
    return {"reply": reply}

# ---------------------------
# Admin endpoints
# ---------------------------
@app.get("/admin/traces")
def traces():
    return get_traces()

@app.get("/admin/evals")
def evals():
    score, total = run_evals()
    return {"score": score, "total": total}

@app.get("/admin/grading")
def grading():
    return grade_traces()

                const res = await fetch("/chat", {
                  method: "POST",
                  headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
                  body: JSON.stringify({ message })
                });

                const data = await res.json();
                return data.reply;
              }
            }
          });
        }
      }, 100);
    });
  </script>
</body>
</html>

1. Backend — backend/main.py (replace fully)

This now includes:

  • Real ChatKit session endpoint

  • Your existing agent /chat endpoint

  • Admin endpoints

  • Frontend serving

python
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel
from backend.agent import run_agent
from backend.storage import get_traces
from backend.evals import run_evals, grade_traces

from fastapi.staticfiles import StaticFiles
from fastapi.responses import FileResponse
import os
import uuid

from openai import OpenAI

client = OpenAI()

app = FastAPI()

# ---------------------------
# Serve frontend
# ---------------------------
frontend_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "..", "frontend")
app.mount("/frontend", StaticFiles(directory=frontend_path), name="frontend")

@app.get("/")
def serve_ui():
    return FileResponse(os.path.join(frontend_path, "index.html"))

# ---------------------------
# REAL ChatKit session endpoint
# ---------------------------
@app.post("/chatkit/session")
def create_session():
    session = client.chatkit.sessions.create(
        user=str(uuid.uuid4())
    )
    return {"client_secret": session.client_secret}

# ---------------------------
# Chat endpoint (ChatKit backend adapter)
# ---------------------------
class ChatRequest(BaseModel):
    message: str

@app.post("/chat")
def chat(req: ChatRequest):
    reply = run_agent(req.message)

    # Example: if reply contains "loan", return widget + actions
    if "loan" in req.message.lower():
        return {
            "reply": {
                "text": reply,
                "widgets": [
                    {
                        "type": "card",
                        "title": "Loan Eligibility",
                        "content": "Eligible for ₹5,00,000 @ 10.5% for 5 years"
                    }
                ],
                "actions": [
                    {"label": "Escalate to RM", "id": "escalate"},
                    {"label": "Download PDF", "id": "download"}
                ]
            }
        }

    return {"reply": {"text": reply}}

# ---------------------------
# Admin endpoints
# ---------------------------
@app.get("/admin/traces")
def traces():
    return get_traces()

@app.get("/admin/evals")
def evals():
    score, total = run_evals()
    return {"score": score, "total": total}

@app.get("/admin/grading")
def grading():
    return grade_traces()

2. Frontend — real ChatKit embed

Replace frontend/index.html fully with this:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>🏦 Banking Assistant (ChatKit)</title>

  <!-- REAL ChatKit runtime -->
  <script src="https://cdn.platform.openai.com/deployments/chatkit/chatkit.js" async></script>

  <style>
    body { margin: 0; font-family: system-ui; background: #f4f6f9; }
    #header { background: #003366; color: white; padding: 12px; font-size: 18px; }
    #chat { height: calc(100vh - 48px); }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <div id="header">🏦 Banking AI Assistant</div>
  <div id="chat"></div>

  <script>
    function waitForChatKit() {
      if (!window.chatkit) {
        setTimeout(waitForChatKit, 100);
        return;
      }

      chatkit.mount(document.getElementById("chat"), {
        api: {
          async getClientSecret() {
            const res = await fetch("/chatkit/session", { method: "POST" });
            const data = await res.json();
            return data.client_secret;
          }
        },

        backend: {
          async sendMessage(message, context) {
            const res = await fetch("/chat", {
              method: "POST",
              headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
              body: JSON.stringify({ message })
            });

            const data = await res.json();

            // Return ChatKit-compatible message
            return {
              text: data.reply.text || data.reply,
              widgets: data.reply.widgets || [],
              actions: data.reply.actions || []
            };
          }
        },

        // Theming (ChatKit feature)
        theme: {
          primary: "#003366",
          background: "#f4f6f9",
          assistantBubble: "#ffffff",
          userBubble: "#003366"
        },

        // Enable attachments (ChatKit capability)
        attachments: {
          enabled: true
        },

        // Enable actions (buttons)
        actions: {
          async onAction(action) {
            alert("Action triggered: " + action.id);
          }
        }
      });
    }

    waitForChatKit();
  </script>
</body>
</html>

Great — that command is used to find the running uvicorn process.
Here’s how to use it properly.

Run this in your terminal:

bash
ps aux | grep uvicorn

You will see output like this:

lua
peerbashap   12345   0.3  ... uvicorn backend.main:app --reload
peerbashap   12367   0.0  ... grep uvicorn

The important line is the one with:

lua
uvicorn backend.main:app --reload

Example:

nginx
peerbashap   12345   ...

👉 The number 12345 is the PID (process ID).

Kill the uvicorn process

Use the PID from your output:

bash
kill -9 12345

After that, uvicorn will be stopped

You can verify:

bash
ps aux | grep uvicorn

Now you should only see the grep uvicorn line.

Easier way (next time)

Instead of all this, just stop it with:

mathematica
Ctrl + C

in the same terminal where you started uvicorn.

You said:
ChatKit | OpenAI API
ERROR: [Errno 48] Address already in use
ChatGPT said:

That error means uvicorn is still running on that port (usually 8000), so when you try to start it again, the port is already occupied.

Here are the fastest ways to fix it.

✅ Quick fix (recommended)

Run this to find the process using port 8000:

macOS / Linux

bash
lsof -i :8000

You’ll see something like:

sql
Python   12345   user   ... TCP *:8000 (LISTEN)

Then kill it:

bash
kill -9 12345

Alternative way (also works)

bash
ps aux | grep uvicorn

Find the line like:

lua
peerbashap   12345   ... uvicorn backend.main:app --reload

Kill it:

bash
kill -9 12345

If you just want to avoid killing anything

You can start uvicorn on a different port instead:

bash
uvicorn backend.main:app --reload --port 8001

Then open:

arduino
http://localhost:8001/

Why this happens

  • You started uvicorn earlier

  • It’s still running in the background

  • New uvicorn tries to bind to the same port

  • OS blocks it → “Address already in use”

Best habit going forward

Always stop uvicorn cleanly with:

Ctrl + C in the terminal where it’s running

If you want, paste your output of:

bash
lsof -i :8000

and I’ll tell you exactly which PID to kill.

Good — the backend is running now.
If you open http://localhost:8001 and see no chat UI, that means the ChatKit script is not loading or not mounting.

Let’s debug this cleanly and fix it.

1. First: confirm the page itself loads

Open this in your browser:

arduino
http://localhost:8001/

Do you at least see the header:

🏦 Banking AI Assistant

If you see a blank page entirely, the issue is FastAPI not serving the HTML correctly.
If you see the header but no chat widget, the issue is ChatKit not loading.

2. Most common cause: ChatKit CDN script not loading

Your page depends on this:

html
<script src="https://cdn.platform.openai.com/deployments/chatkit/chatkit.js" async></script>

If that script fails to load, window.chatkit will never exist → nothing renders.

Check this quickly:

Open DevTools in your browser:

  • Right click → Inspect → Console tab

Do you see errors like:

  • chatkit is not defined

  • Failed to load resource

  • Blocked by CORS

  • net::ERR_BLOCKED_BY_CLIENT

If yes → that’s the root cause.

3. Quick test: check if ChatKit loaded

In the browser console (DevTools → Console), type:

js
window.chatkit

Expected:

You should see an object (not undefined).

If you see:

javascript
undefined

→ The ChatKit script did NOT load.

4. Why this often happens

Common reasons:

  • Corporate firewall blocks cdn.platform.openai.com

  • Adblocker blocks the script

  • Browser privacy setting blocks third-party scripts

  • Network DNS blocks OpenAI CDN

This is extremely common in enterprise networks.

5. Quick workaround to confirm this is the issue

Try opening your app in:

  • Safari (if you’re using Chrome)

  • Chrome Incognito (extensions disabled)

  • Mobile hotspot (not corporate Wi-Fi)

If it suddenly works → you have network/CDN blocking, not a code issue.

6. If you want: I can give you a fallback that guarantees UI works

If your network blocks ChatKit CDN, you have two real options:

Option A (Still official ChatKit, but self-host JS)

  • Download ChatKit JS bundle

  • Serve it from your FastAPI server instead of CDN
    → Works even in locked-down enterprise networks

Option B (React ChatKit SDK)

  • Use @openai/chatkit-react

  • Bundle locally with Vite / React
    → No external CDN dependency

Enterprises usually prefer Option B.

    chatkit.mount(document.getElementById("chat"), {

        assistantBubble: "#ffffff",
